verses.text: Then I saw an angel coming down from heaven, holding the key to the Abyss and a great chain in his hand.
verses.comment: The Abyss, or 'bottomless pit,' is referenced elsewhere as the dwelling place of demonic forces (cf. Rev. 9:1). The angel having authority shows God’s sovereignty over all spiritual powers.

verses.text: He seized the dragon, that ancient serpent, who is the devil and Satan, and bound him for a thousand years.
verses.comment: The identification of the dragon as the ancient serpent directly connects this enemy to the events in Genesis (Gen. 3:1). The thousand years has been understood both literally and as symbolically representing a long period.

verses.text: And he threw him into the Abyss, shut it, and sealed it over him, so that he might not deceive the nations any longer, until the thousand years are finished. After that he must be released for a short time.
verses.comment: The motif of sealing recalls the authority given for judgment in the apocalyptic tradition. The temporary restraint of evil reflects God’s control, allowing a time of peace before a final confrontation.

verses.text: Then I saw thrones, and those seated on them were given authority to judge. I also saw the souls of those who had been beheaded because of their testimony about Jesus and for the word of God, who had not worshiped the beast or its image and had not received its mark on their foreheads or on their hands. They came to life and reigned with Christ for a thousand years.
verses.comment: The reference to thrones and authority to judge echoes Daniel’s vision (Dan. 7:9). The martyrs’ resurrection implies a special reward for faithfulness, pointing towards the importance of perseverance and spiritual union with Christ.

verses.text: The rest of the dead did not come to life until the thousand years were finished. This is the first resurrection.
verses.comment: The 'first resurrection' distinguishes the blessed and holy from others (cf. John 5:28–29). This passage has implications for beliefs about life after death and final judgment.

verses.text: Blessed and holy is the one who shares in the first resurrection. Over them the second death has no power, but they will be priests of God and of Christ, and they will reign with Him for a thousand years.
verses.comment: Being 'priests of God and of Christ' points to participation in Christ's mediating role (Rev. 1:6). The second death refers to final separation from God—those united to Christ are secure from it.

verses.text: When the thousand years are finished, Satan will be released from his prison
verses.comment: The release of Satan marks the final period of testing and conflict before the ultimate victory of God.

verses.text: and will go out to deceive the nations at the four corners of the earth, Gog and Magog, to gather them for battle. Their number is like the sand of the sea.
verses.comment: Gog and Magog reference Ezekiel’s prophecy (Ezek. 38), symbolizing universal opposition to God. The huge number emphasizes the scale of the final confrontation.

verses.text: And they marched across the breadth of the earth and surrounded the camp of the saints and the beloved city. But fire came down from heaven and consumed them.
verses.comment: The 'camp of the saints' and 'beloved city' often symbolize God's people gathered in unity. The descent of fire recalls God's decisive judgment and protection of His own.

verses.text: And the devil who deceived them was thrown into the lake of fire and sulfur, where the beast and the false prophet are, and they will be tormented day and night forever and ever.
verses.comment: The eternal punishment of the devil and other enemies highlights the finality and justice of God's reign. The lake of fire is a symbol pointing to ultimate, everlasting separation.

verses.text: Then I saw a great white throne and the one who sat on it. Earth and sky fled from His presence, and no place was found for them.
verses.comment: The white throne signifies complete purity and authority in judgment. The act of creation fleeing suggests the awesome holiness of God and the renewal that follows.

verses.text: And I saw the dead, great and small, standing before the throne, and books were opened. And another book was opened, which is the Book of Life. And the dead were judged by what was written in the books, according to what they had done.
verses.comment: The Book of Life assures salvation for those whose names are written in it. Judgment according to deeds underscores both accountability and grace.

verses.text: And the sea gave up the dead that were in it, and Death and Hades gave up the dead that were in them, and all were judged, each one according to what they had done.
verses.comment: Resurrection from every realm points to the universality of judgment. God's perfect justice is revealed to all, matching other biblical statements (Ps. 7:8).

verses.text: Then Death and Hades were thrown into the lake of fire. This is the second death, the lake of fire.
verses.comment: Death and Hades being destroyed signifies the complete victory of Christ over sin, death, and separation. This consummation verifies prophetic fulfillment from the beginning (Rev. 1:18).

verses.text: And if anyone's name was not found written in the Book of Life, he was thrown into the lake of fire.
verses.comment: The assurance of salvation is connected to the Book of Life, a recurring biblical image representing communion with Christ and the reward for remaining faithful and united with His people.
